The point $Q% $ cannot be reached from the point $S$ through movements along the two vectors% $\vec{v_{1}}$ and $\vec{v_{2}}$.}} \@add@centering \@add@centering\end{figure} \par It is useful to keep this geometric interpretation of parallel vectors % in mind, but we wish to generalize this concept and express it in algebraic % terms. \par \@@section{subsection}{Sx2.SSx1}{}{}{}{Algebraic Representation of % Parallelism} \par Here is a first attempt at defining parallelism in algebraic terms: \par Algebraically, we say that $\vec{v_{1}}$ and $\vec{v_{2}}$ are parallel % if $\vec{v_{1}}=c\vec{v_{2}}$ for some scalar $c$. \par This is equivalent to saying that \@@amsalign$\displaystyle\vec{v_{1}}$&$\displaystyle=c\vec{v_{2}}$\ $\displaystyle(1)\vec{v_{1}}+(-c)\vec{v_{2}}$&$\displaystyle=\vec{0}$ or in other words, two vectors are parallel if a \emph{linear combination} of % $\vec{v_{1}}$ and $\vec{v_{2}}$ can produce the zero vector. \par What about higher dimensions, say $ bR^{3}$? If we want to expand this % definition of parallelism, we may wish to express algebraically that $\vec{v_{% 1}},\vec{v_{2}}$ lie in the same plane. If we consider this though, it is % apparent that \emph{any} two vectors lie in the same plane in $ bR^{3}$. If % instead we consider the case of three vectors in $ bR^{3}$, this is no longer% the case -- for instance, the three vectors that correspond to the three axes% $x,y,z$ do not lie in the same plane. It is of interest then to characterize % when exactly three vectors will lie in the same plane. \par \@@section{paragraph}{Sx2.SSx1.SSS0.Px1}{}{}{}{Question:}When will $\vec{% v_{1}},\vec{v_{2}},\vec{v_{3}}$ lie in the same plane in $ bR^{3}$? \par We can think of this in the following way: if the three vectors lie in % the same plane, then a linear combination of $\vec{v_{1}}$ and $\vec{v_{2}}$ % should be able to produce $\vec{v_{3}}$: \@@amsalign$\displaystyle\vec{v_{3}}$&$\displaystyle=c_{1}\vec{v_{1}}+c_{2}% \vec{v_{2}}$ Again, we can rewrite this equation and find a familiar expression: \@@amsalign$\displaystyle\vec{v_{3}}+(-c_{1})\vec{v_{1}}+(-c_{2})\vec{v_{2}}$ that is, $\vec{v_{1}},\vec{v_{2}},\vec{v_{3}}$ can form a linear combination % to produce the zero vector. \par \@@section{section}{Sx3}{}{}{}{Coplanarity} \par The idea of {coplanarity} can be thought of as the capacity for a linear% combination of vectors to produce the zero vector. \par  ramebox[][r]{  egin{minipage}{0.0pt} Let $S$ be a set of vectors, \@@amsalign$\displaystyle S=\left\{\vec{v_{1}},\vec{v_{2}},\dots,\vec{v_{k}}% ight\}$ $S$ is a {linearly dependent} set if a \emph{non-trivial} linear combination % of vectors can produce the zero vector. \par
\par
Otherwise, $S$ is {linearly independent}. \end{minipage} } \par There are some important points to understand with this definition. % First, when we say a linear combination that is equal to zero, we mean \@@amsalign$\displaystyle c_{1}\vec{v_{1}}+c_{2}\vec{v_{2}}+\dots+c_{k}\vec{v_% {k}}$&$\displaystyle=\vec{0}$ One solution to this equation is obvious: letting $c_{i}=0$ for all $i=1,2,% \dots,k$. This is called the {trivial} solution. \par A {non-trivial} linear combination resulting in the zero vector is one % in which at least one of the coefficients $c_{i}$ is nonzero. \par \@@section{paragraph}{Sx3.SSx1.SSS0.Px1}{}{}{}{Example.} Consider the set of vectors $S$ in the space $ bR^{2}$: \@@amsalign$\displaystyle S=\left\{ egin{bmatrix}1\ 2\end{bmatrix}, egin{bmatrix}-3\ 4\end{bmatrix}ight\}$ \par \@@section{paragraph}{Sx3.SSx1.SSS0.Px2}{}{}{}{Question:}Is $S$ (linearly% ) independent or dependent? \@@amsalign$\displaystyle c_{1} egin{bmatrix}1\ 2\end{bmatrix}+c_{2} egin{bmatrix}-3\ 4\end{bmatrix}$&$\displaystyle= egin{bmatrix}0\ 0\end{bmatrix}$ This question boils down to: can a non-trivial linear combination equal $\vec{% 0}$? \par If we look at this equation, it should remind us of the \emph{column % picture}. That is, we are looking for the solutions of the system \@@amsalign$\displaystyle\left[ egin{matrix}[rr|r]1&-3&0\ 2&4&0\end{matrix}ight]$ Thinking about it, it may be enlightening to consider what exactly we are % looking for. We now have the tools to solve the system, but are we simply % looking for a solution, or something more, or something less than a particular% solution? \par Observe that such a system will always be consistent. The reason for % this is that the trivial solution $c_{1}=c_{2}=0$ will always be a solution. A% system becomes inconsistent only when a pivot enters the constant column, and% since the entries in the constant column are all zero, none of the row % operations we know can ever produce a non-zero entry in that column. Thus this% system will always be consistent. \par The question of importance then is: does this system have a non-zero % solution? This equates to asking the question of whether this system has more % than one solution or not. If you recall, we have found that linear systems may% have either no solution, one solution, or infinitely many solutions. Since % this system has at least one solution, we want to know whether it in fact has % infinitely many solutions. When attempting to answer this question, what % should come to mind is the \emph{rank of a matrix}, or the presence of free % variables. If there are free variables, then the system will have infinitely % many solutions. \par Going back to the example at hand, we put the matrix in row echelon form% : \@@amsalign$\displaystyle\left[ egin{matrix}[rr|r]1&-3&0\ 2&4&0\end{matrix}ight]\xrightarrow[]{-2R_{1}+R_{2}}\left[ egin{matrix}[rr|r% ]1&-3&0\ 0&10&0\end{matrix}ight]$ This matrix has a rank of $2$, and thus has no free variables. Thus it has a % unique solution, which is the zero or trivial solution. Because of this, it % has no non-trivial linear combination that produces the zero vector. Thus the % set of vectors is independent. Here we have used the tools we have developed % to test the linear dependence of a set of vectors. \par An important thing to note is that we are looking at a specific type of % linear system. The right-hand side column vector in the case of determining % linear independence is the zero vector: \@@amsalign$\displaystyle c_{1} egin{bmatrix}1\ 2\end{bmatrix}+c_{2} egin{bmatrix}-3\ 4\end{bmatrix}$&$\displaystyle= egin{bmatrix}0\ 0\end{bmatrix}\Leftarrow	ext{Right hand side is zero vector}$ This type of system is referred to as a {homogeneous system}: \@@amsalign$\displaystyle\mathbf{A}\vec{x}$&$\displaystyle=\vec{0}$ Such a system is associated with \emph{linear independence}, whereas a system % such as $\mathbf{A}\vec{x}=\vec{b}$ is associated with \emph{linear span}. \par \@@section{paragraph}{Sx3.SSx1.SSS0.Px3}{}{}{}{Example.} Let us consider another example.
